quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: If you don't have product market fit, and if you don't have a good enough growth strategy for at least one side of your marketplace, just forget about all this marketplace stuff. Focus on this core exchange of value, go deep with one side of the marketplace and see if you can rely on some crutch, some hack for the other side for time being.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: Pick the hardest side. Find a way to jumpstart one side, find a way to hack one side, play one player mode is what it's also called sometimes, but try to find a way to tap into existing channels that have one side of your marketplace already latent.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: Liquidity is how marketplaces win. It's this measure of your ability to match buyers and sellers efficiently, it's how quickly and efficiently people can find what they're looking for on your platform. It's literally at the center of your vision, it's why you exist as a marketplace is to connect the two.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: Find this threshold, find this predictor that tends to plateau that correlates strongly with retention but with also the transaction happening, and that's the metric that you can predict. That's a metric that's so much more actionable for teams to work against.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: Product market fit is independent of your marketplace dynamics. You might have a great product that provides amazing value to both sides, but you have yet to crack the flywheel on the supply side. My advice would be to measure your product market fit the way you would for a normal company.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: You want this long tail of buyers and sellers without a handful of big players controlling the market. You also want a relatively uniform set of needs so supply can be commoditized to some extent. And high enough barrier in the matchmaking - how hard it is for people to find each other today.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: People who build marketplaces tend to want to give a lot of control to the users because this is what users want. I think the mistake is that you unknowingly fragment your supply in a way that has a much more meaningful impact on the health of your marketplace than you suspect.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: Work on ways to make this checkbox affect the ranking but not the actual filtering. We know you prefer a smoke machine, but we're intelligent enough to know it's probably not a deal breaker for you.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: I see a lot of larger companies operating for too long as one-sided businesses. Many large marketplaces only thinking about their demand side funnel. My advice is, if you're doing this you're missing out on half of your business. Marketplaces are very laggy, so once your network effects start to die down it turns into this moment of panic.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: I'm a huge believer in market forces and empowerment. Provide guardrails for what a good experience is in your marketplace, set a clear bar for quality, and provide the right coaching and tools for supply to be successful. Then take a step back and see where the gaps are.

quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.text: We would pay our best drivers $35 per mentor session. The mentors were our very best drivers, and they were evangelists for the brand. They would share personal tips on when and where to drive. This created tremendous leverage and social proof for new drivers who were on the fence about taking strangers into their car.

takeaways: Pre-PMF, ignore marketplace dynamics entirely - focus on finding a growth strategy for the harder side of your marketplace and hack the other side temporarily.
Liquidity is the ultimate measure of marketplace success - find the market health metric that predicts it (like ETAs for ride-sharing) and make that actionable for teams.
Resist the urge to give users too many filters and controls - each preference fragments your supply and hurts marketplace health more than you realize.
Treat your marketplace as two separate products requiring two separate PMF validations - most companies neglect supply too long and face a crisis when network effects weaken.
Leverage your best supply as a scalable growth engine - Lyft's mentor program outperformed professional sales teams and allowed them to match Uber's footprint with a fraction of resources.

contrarian_candidates.why: Tells marketplace founders to ignore marketplace dynamics entirely until they have PMF - counter to common advice to obsess over supply/demand balance
Claims PMF is independent of marketplace dynamics, which challenges the common belief that marketplaces have fundamentally different PMF criteria
Argues against giving users control and customization options - counter to typical user-centric product advice
